When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it is derived (for example, if it moves above a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return to the original), it often finds itself in a different environment from that in which it was previously.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it had before.
The original population has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to resemble less and less the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will appear so different that they will no longer be considered members of the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

The technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense according to which the destiny of humanity is dictated by a underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technologies.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: technological development itself is a process that transcends cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
The massive possession of cars also leads to a greater incidence of road accidents, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat bodily injuries.

Germany was a common enemy during World War II, which led to cooperation between the USSR and the United States. At the end of the war, deep conflicts between their different systems, methods and cultures ended their cooperation.
Two years after the end of the war, the old allies became enemies and the cold war began.
It would last for the next 40 years and see real battles, through proxy armies, on battlefields both in Africa and Asia, in Afghanistan, in Cuba and in many other places.
The 17 September 1939, the Polish defense was already broken, and the only hope was to retreat and reorganize along the Romanian head of bridge.

But these plans became obsolete almost overnight, when more than 800,000 Soviet troops arrived and created the Belarusian and Ukrainian fronts after they invaded the east of Poland, violating the Riga Peace Treaty, the Soviet-Polish non-aggression pact, as well as other bilateral and multilateral international treaties, whether bilateral or multilateral.
The use of ships for the transport of goods is by far the most efficient way to move large quantities of people and goods across the oceans.

The work of the navies has traditionally been to ensure that your country retains the ability to move your people and your goods, while interfering with the ability of your enemy to move his people and his goods.

One of the most recent and remarkable examples of this situation was the North Atlantic campaign during World War II. The Americans were trying to get troops and equipment across the Atlantic to help the British.
At the same time, the German Navy, using mainly U-Boats, tried to stop this traffic.
If the Allies had failed, Germany would probably have been able to conquer Britain just as she did for the rest of Europe.
It seems that goats were domesticated for the first time around 10,000 years ago in the Zagros Mountains in Iran.
The ancient cultures and tribes started keeping them close to them to have easy access to milk, fur, meat and skins.

Domestic goats were usually kept in herds that wandered on the hills or other grazing areas, often cared for by shepherds who were most often children or adolescents, similar to the term more commonly known as shepherds. These pastoral methods have always been in use today.
The "wagonways" were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the tracks for wagons were simply wooden planks laid parallel to each other, they allowed horses pulling them to reach greater speeds and to carry heavier loads than on the slightly more uneven roads of the day.
The crossbars were introduced early enough to keep the tracks in place. However, it soon became apparent that the tracks would be more effective if they were fitted with a strip of iron on top.
It has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.
The first means of locomotion was walking: humans began walking upright two million years ago with the arrival of Homo Erectus ("upright man").
Their predecessors, the australopithecines, did not walk upright as usual.
Bipedal specializations are found in Australopithecus fossils from 4.2 to 3.9 million years ago, although Sahelanthropus could walk on two legs already seven million years ago.

It is clear that the world has changed a lot due to the scientific and technological progress made by human beings, and that the problems have become more important due to the overpopulation and extravagant lifestyle of humanity.

After its adoption by the Congress on July 4, a manuscript signed by the President of Congress John Hancock and the Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few blocks away, to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 specimens were made, today known as "Dunlap Broads".
The first public reading of the document took place in the hall of the Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap leaves still known to exist are the oldest known copies of the document. The original handwritten manuscript has not survived.
Many palaeontologists think today that a group of dinosaurs survived and is still alive. They are called birds.
Very few people consider them dinosaurs because they have wings and can fly.
But there are a lot of things about birds that still look like dinosaurs.
They are covered with scales and have claws, they lay eggs and walk on their hind legs like T-Rexes.
Practically all computers used today are based on manipulating information that is coded in binary numbers.
A binary number can have only one of two values: 0 or 1. These numbers are called binary digits, or bits for computer jargon.

The best indicator of internal poisoning is probably the presence of an open container of drugs or household chemicals that are toxic.
Consult the label for specific first aid instructions for this poison.
The term "insect" is used by entomologists in a formal sense for this group of insects.
This term derives from an old familiarity with bed bugs, which are very well adapted to parasitize humans.
Red worms, like bed bugs, are nidicolous, that is, adapted to live in the nest or the habitat of their host.
In the United States, there are about 400,000 known cases of multiple sclerosis (MS), which makes it the most common neurological disease in young and middle-aged adults.
Multiple sclerosis is a disease that affects the central nervous system, composed of the brain, spinal cord and optic nerve.
Research has shown that women are twice as likely to have multiple sclerosis as men.
A couple may very well feel that it is not in their interest, nor in the interest of the child, to care for a baby.

Many rhythms observed in physiology and behavior depend on the presence of endogenous cycles and their production by biological clocks.
Periodic rhythms, which are not simply responses to external periodic stimuli, have been documented for most living things, including bacteria, fungi, plants and animals.
Biological clocks are self-sustaining oscillators that will continue a cycle of operation for a certain period of time, even in the absence of external stimulation.
The Hershey-Chase experiment was one of the main indications that DNA was a genetic material.
Hershey and Chase used phages, or viruses, to implant their own DNA into a bacterium.
They conducted two experiments to label either the phage DNA with radioactive phosphorus, or the phage protein with radioactive sulfur.
Mutations can have many different effects depending on the type of mutation, the importance of the part of the genetic material affected and if the affected cells are germ cells.

The ecotourism is interested in people who want to visit natural areas in order to enjoy the landscape, especially the fauna and flora.
Hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, visiting parks and studying information on the ecosystem are examples of on-site activities.
One can, for example, go to see, photograph and discover the orang-utans of Borneo.
Every morning, people leave the small towns of the countryside in their cars to go to work and cross other people who are going to work in the countryside they just left.
In this dynamic transport shuttle, each is in some way connected to a transport system based on private cars and supports it.
The science now shows that this massively carbon-based economy has displaced the biosphere from its state of stability that has supported human evolution for two million years.
Everyone belongs to society and uses transport systems. Almost everyone complains about transport systems.
In developed countries, it is rare to hear so many complaints about the quality of water or the collapse of bridges.
Why do transport systems generate such complaints, why do they break down daily? Are transport engineers simply incompetent? Or is there something more fundamental going on?
Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and private vehicles between two points, and of the interactions they exert between themselves.
Unfortunately, it is difficult to study traffic flow because the behavior of drivers cannot be predicted with a hundred percent certainty.
Unfortunately, drivers tend to act within a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable consistency and can be represented mathematically approximately.
To better represent the traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density and (3) speed.
These relationships help to plan, design, and operate road facilities.
Insects were the first animals to fly. Their ability to fly allowed them to escape more easily from their enemies and to find more effectively food and companions.
Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings along their bodies.
This gives them more hiding places from predators.
Today, the only insects that cannot fold their wings are dragonflies and ephemera.

Some thought he was right, but many believed the opposite: that the solar system moved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).
It seems reasonable, because the Earth doesn't seem to move, doesn't it?
The Amazon River is the second longest and largest river on Earth. It carries more than eight times the volume of water of the second largest river.
The Amazon is also the largest river in the world, sometimes reaching 10 km in width.
Not less than 20 percent of the water that pours from the rivers of the planet into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 mi) long. It collects water from thousands of small rivers.

The Vatican City State drafts its legislation and official communications in Italian.
Italian is also the language of everyday life used by most people who work in the state, while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.

The thickness of the crust is about 70 km on the visible side and 100 km on the hidden side.

Theories of content are centered on the search for what makes people feel good or attractive.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that have been internalized over the course of their maturation into adulthood.
These theories examine what drives some people to want the things they do and what, in their environment, drives them to do or not do certain things.
Two popular content theories are the Maslow hierarchy of needs theory and the Herzberg two-factor theory.
In general, two behaviors can emerge when a manager becomes the boss of former colleagues. On one end of the spectrum is trying to remain the good friend (or the good friend).
This type of manager has a hard time taking unpopular decisions, taking disciplinary actions, conducting evaluations, assigning responsibilities, and holding others accountable.
At the other end of the spectrum, one transforms into an unrecognizable individual who feels he or she must change everything that the group has created up to now and do things his or her own way.
After all, the leader is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to disagreements between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are subject to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members because their teams can meet in different time zones, which may not be understood by their local management.
The presence of a real "team invisible" (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique element of a virtual team.
"The invisible team" is the management team to which each member is accountable. It establishes standards for each of them.

The development of new technologies allows us to see and study brain structures and processes that have never been seen before.

Although Artificial Intelligence is often strongly associated with science fiction, it represents a very important part of computer science that studies the intelligent behavior, learning and adaptive behavior of a machine.
Artificial intelligence research aims at automating tasks requiring an intelligent approach by machines.
Among the examples are control, planning and programming, the ability to respond to diagnostics and questions of clients, as well as recognition of handwriting, voice and face.
These practices have led to distinct disciplines, focused on the contribution of solutions to everyday problems.

Excursions are an integral part of any school class. Often, a teacher would like to take her students to places where a bus trip is not possible.

The solution is provided by technology in the form of virtual educational outings. Students can watch ancient objects in a museum, visit an aquarium, or admire a beautiful artwork while sitting with their class.
Practically participating in an excursion is also a great way to think about a trip and share your experiences with future generations.

For example, students from Bennet School in North Carolina design a website each year about their visit to the capital of the state. Each year, the website is updated, but the old versions are kept online to serve as an album.

Blogs can also help students improve their writing skills. Even if students often try the blogging experience with a neglected grammar and spelling, the fact of having a public usually evolves the situation.
As students are often the most critical audience, the blogger begins to try to improve his writing to avoid criticism.
"It also forces students to better understand the world around them."
Blogs are a tool that stimulates collaboration and encourages students to extend their learning beyond the traditional school day.

"When used properly, blogs can allow students to strengthen their analytical and critical thinking abilities: by actively reacting to online content, they can confront their opinions with those of others and present their own views on specific topics."
Ottawa is the charming bilingual capital of Canada and has a large number of art galleries and museums that highlight the past and present of Canada.
You will find Niagara Falls to the south and Muskoka to the north with its pristine natural beauty.
These measures, and many others, make Ontario what foreigners consider to be the quintessence of Canada.
There are large areas further north that are quite sparsely populated and some are almost uninhabited in their natural state.

The East African islands are located in the Indian Ocean, off the east African coast.
Madagascar is the largest country in the world, and even a continent on its own, in terms of fauna.
Most of the small islands are independent nations, or associated with France, and are known for being luxury resorts.
The Arabs also brought the practice of Islam to the islands and this religion spread widely to Comoros and Mayotte.
The European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century, when the Portuguese explorer Vasco de Gama discovered the Cape route that connects Europe to India.
To the north, the region is bounded by the Sahel, and to the south and to the west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE, and was used by Phoenicians, Romans and the Almohads as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and rebuilt it and christened it Casa Branca, abandoned it in 1755 after a earthquake.
The sultan of Morocco rebuilt the city under the name of Daru l-Badya, and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in Morocco for shopping.

In the vicinity of the old medina, one can easily find places where one can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tajines, pottery, leather goods, narguilés and all kinds of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, in particular the city centre.
Although Goma is reasonably safe, any visit outside of Goma should be done with caution to understand the ongoing fighting in the North Kivu province.
The city is also the starting point for the climb of the Nyiragongo Volcano and for gorilla tracking treks among the cheapest in Africa.
You can use boda-boda (motor taxi) to get around Goma. The normal price (local) is about 500 francs congolais for a short ride.
Combined with its relative remoteness, "Tombouctou" has become a metaphor for distant and exotic countries.
Today, Tombouctou is a poor city, despite its reputation as a tourist attraction, and it has an airport.
In 1990, it was added to the World Heritage List in Danger, due to the threat of sand dunes.
It was one of the main stages of the program "Wonders of the African World" of Henry Louis Gates on PBS.
The city contrasts sharply with the cities of the rest of the country, because it has a style more Arab than African.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa and runs along the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River border to the south.
The total area of the park is 19,500 km², which is divided into 14 ecozones, each of which harbours a specific fauna.
This is one of the most famous amusement parks in South Africa and considered to be the crown jewel of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entry and conservation fees for the park.
It can be advantageous to get a Wild Card that gives access to some of South Africa's parks, as well as to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island gives its name to the territory of Hong Kong and is the main attraction for many tourists.
The row of buildings that forms the horizon of Hong Kong has been compared to a scintillating bar graph, which reveals itself by reflection in the waters of Victoria Harbour.
For admiring the most beautiful views of Hong Kong, leave the island and join the Kowloon Bay front located on the opposite side.
Most of the urban development in Hong Kong Island is concentrated on the land plots along the northern shore.
This is the place that the British colonists have invested. So, it seems to me to be a good starting point, if you are looking for evidence of colonial history in this region.
The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 mi) from the coast to the backwaters of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located in India is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests, however, are not composed only of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last vestiges of the majestic jungles that once covered the plains of the Ganges.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 sq km, of which about one third is covered by water/marshy areas.
Sundarbans is a national park since 1966, you can find about 400 Royal Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The buses leave the intercity bus station (on the other side of the river) throughout the day, but most, particularly those that serve the east and Jakar/Bumthang, leave between 6:30 and 7:30 in the morning.
Inter-district buses are often full, so it is advisable to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most districts are served by small Japanese boats, which are comfortable and robust.
Taxi buses are a quick and comfortable way to get to places nearby, such as Paro (150 Nu) and Punakha (200 Nu).
The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It overhangs the Oyapock River to connect the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers stand at a height of 83 metres; it is 378 metres long and has two lanes of 3.50 metres wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but it was opened to traffic in March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.
The Guarani were the most important indigenous group inhabiting what is now the east of Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters and practicing subsistence agriculture.
Other indigenous tribes who inhabited the Chaco, such as the Guaycurú or the Payaguá, survived mainly through fishing, hunting, or gathering.
In the 16th century, Paraguay, formerly called the "Giant Province of the Indies," was born from the meeting between the Spanish conquerors and the indigenous populations.
The Spaniards inaugurated the period of colonialism, which lasted three centuries.
Since the foundation of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has been able to preserve a large part of its character and identity.
Argentina is known for having one of the best teams and among the best polo players in the world.
The biggest tournament of the year takes place in December on the polo fields of Las Cañitas.
In addition, smaller tournaments and matches are sometimes organized here at other times of the year.
For information on polo tournaments and places to buy tickets for polo matches, see the Argentine Polo Association.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands Pound (FKP), which is equivalent to a British pound (GBP).
The money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands located at Stanley, opposite the FIC West store.
The pound sterling is a widely accepted currency in the islands, while at Stanley, American dollars and credit cards are also often accepted.
On the nearby islands, credit cards will probably not be accepted, even if British and American currency may be accepted. Talk to the owners ahead of time to agree on a method of payment.
It is almost impossible to exchange money from the Falkland Islands outside the islands, so change it before leaving the islands.
Montevideo is located south of the equator, so winter in the northern hemisphere corresponds to summer there and vice versa.
Montevideo is located in the subtropical zone and summer temperatures exceeding 30 °C are common.
Winter can be deceivingly cold: temperatures rarely fall below zero, but wind and humidity combine to give the impression that it is colder than the thermometer says.
There is no real "rainy season" and "dry season". Rainfall is fairly constant throughout the year.
Although many of the animals in the park are used to seeing humans, they are wild animals; please do not feed them or disturb them.
According to the park authorities, it is necessary to be at least 100 yards (91 m) from bears and wolves and 25 yards (23 m) from all other wild animals.
As docile as they may appear, bison, elk, moose, bear, and almost all large animals can attack.
Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they didn't keep enough distance. These animals are large, wild and potentially dangerous, so give them space.
Finally, know that odors attract bears and other wild animals, so avoid carrying or cooking odorsome foods and keep the camp clean.
Apia is the capital of Samoa. The city is located on the island of Upolu and has about 40,000 inhabitants.
Apia was founded in the 1850s and is the official capital of Samoa since 1959.

The beaches of North Shore (in the North Harbour district) are on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay to the north to Devonport to the south.
Most beaches are sandy and safe to swim in, and most are shaded by pohutukawa trees.
The Tamaki Drive beaches are located on the Waitemata Harbour, in the chic Mission Bay and Saint Heliers neighbourhoods in the centre of Auckland.

A walking safari (also called bush walking, walking safari or footing) consists of walking, either for a few hours or for several days.

The stirrups are supports for the rider's feet, which hang from each side of the saddle.
They offer more stability to the user, but they can pose a security problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has one foot caught in the stirrups, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a pointed toe and a smooth and narrow sole.
